threads.com:
/vst/ is a place to discuss all types of strategy video games, including both turn-based and real-time strategy, turn-based and real-time tactics, single-player and multi-player (including MOBAs). All platforms are welcome.

Does this mean discussion of strategy games is banned on other video game boards? No! /vst/ is just a separate board specifically focused on strategy games where discussions about your favorite games can thrive.

Please familiarize yourself with the rules and remember to use the spoiler function where appropriate!

Please note that, like /v/, "Generals"—long-term, one-after-the-other, recurring threads about a specific game are not permitted on /vst/. Such threads belong on >>>/vg/

>>1261107
The problem with 1UPT is that it brought tactical gameplay WITHOUT accommodating the fact that the whole game is set on a strategic map. In a typical wargame map you have open space where your units can maneuver freely and each engagement is meaningful as you can't easily requisition more units. In nuCiv, you have giants who use mountains as cover, get piled up near isthmuses and infantries can only move two tiles per turn, so instead of clever flanking the tactic boils down to bloodbath grindfest. Also since you have infinite cities producing infinite units all tactics are moot considering that it's always the one that can outproduce the other than win, same with the old doomstack.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
I think something like High Elf Bard was the "default" hero I always played for my favorite kind of campaign. You're weak as dirt, but Bard let you get "Leadership" (or something like that), which gave you extra points in the deployment phase. So you could start the match with a full army if you wanted.
Or.... you could have a retinue of high level stuff that could you take with you in every mission, points be damned.
Additionally, you had a skill that gave extra "Morale" so all your units attacked faster, if you stacked it, significantly so.
Lastly, High Elf hero gave you access to Healing Magic that was class-independent, so you could keep your high level retinue alive, or even ressurect them if they ended up dying.

For retinue you could honestly do whatever and it worked. I preferred an entire army of Dryads, who could cross the map in like 10 seconds, were faster than anything and had ranged magic attacks that could not be reduced by any kind of armor.

Demon Pyromancer was also a rather fun gimmick. You could take Succubi with you in your retinue, and anything they kill gets converted to a soul, which your Demon Pyro could attack for infinite mana. Since for some reason your damage spells also hit souls, you could chain cast damage spells from long range forever as long as your succibi would kill the occasional peasant / low level mook.

last_replies.com:
>>1220568
WC3 is a legendary campaign and I find it bizzare to see it get so much hate.
I will say that I didn't like the nelf campaign because it refuses to give you key units for a long time and I never cared about the nelfs as much as the other races. It's also annoying that the game will deny you key heroes in other campaigns like the horde not getting blademaster, which is really huge for them. It's also frustrating when you're forced to play late game as horde which is a faction with zero strong lategame units (tauren are trash).
That said, overall it's fantastic. The story isn't amazing but Arthas' downfall is one of the best character arcs I've seen in a video game. His decisions all make sense and it isn't until Northrend that he really goes too far but it's not difficult to see why he wanted to: he was so close to his goal and had sacrificed everything for it. The inventory and level system gives a sense of progression through the campaign and also rewards side objectives and exploration well.
TFT is more hero focused and I like that but it's clear that parts of it were rushed a bit. Illidan is such a simp too.
Imo it's easily one of the best rts campaigns ever made.

>>1262465
It's an awesome game.
>How does trade work?
You'll learn the game actually works off of supply and demand so building the same workshops everywhere will quickly run your economy into the ground due to upkeep and lack of profits whereas if you have a producing city and several populated cities that will realistically buy from it nearby your profits will skyrocket. Read a guide for more, there's a fair bit to it.
>How do you git gud at warfare?
To be honest, even with many armies I still mess up deploying them and end up just swarming my enemies for the most part. The battle system is weird to me and I never can get a feel for what works and what doesn't so I just take what I think is cool since numbers seem to matter more most of the time.
>Avoid peasant rebellions?
If you work the peasants for centuries they're going to want to rebel no matter what. Some people recommend giving them 10 - 30 turns to rest after 80 - 100 turns of work. To be fair, there's not really much reason you need to have peasants cutting down nearby forests after everything else has been built so this system can save you a lot of headache. The noble rebellions are a way worse threat.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
Why are hexfags so fucking retarded they cannot see the forest for the trees?

See picrel for why why the "diagonal movement problem" hexfags try to ascribe to squares doesn't actually exist - because you are moving in tiles, not actual distance! It doesn't matter that you have moved 1.41 feet diagonally, when you would have moved only 1 foot orthgonaly, becasue YOU ARE NOT MOVING IN REAL DISTANCE, YOU ARE MOVING IN TILES.
See picrel, it takes the exact same amount of tiles to move from one corner to the next diagonally, that it takes to move from one corner to the next orthogonally.
Yes the real distance is larger, but that does not matter, since the game is structured in tiles, not real distance!

Hexxfagging is unirinically Reddit-style thinking - believing you are some sort of expert and can overturn years of time-tested methods because you have learned some arbitrary fun fact (in this case that distance from one center of a square to the center of diagonal square is larger than the distance to the center of a orthogonal square).

TL;DR: 1 tile = 1 tile, always

2h flails have +10% armor ignore on their basic attack (40%) alongside the usual +20 damage that two handed swords maces and hammers get, but if they hit head the ignore is increased by +10%. If you have flail mastery that bonus on head hit is doubled, meaning that two handed flails will do 60% armor ignore on a head hit. You want headhunter with this which is kind of a dead perk when using the 3 headed flail (but not a dead perk when using a named 1h flail) but eh, if you only intended to use 3 headed vs nomads and gilders then you can probably skip duelist and still have recover and everything you'd want

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1262841
Need some help on some basic ideas. I will do some basic 'how does the game function' before going into detail. The basics of the game's format is:
1. Hex Grid
2. You control a small squad rather than one character, between 4 and 24 individuals
3. Your overall character points are split between all individuals (XP amount per battle being static then distributed between all there), so you can have 4 very strong guys or many weak guys

Here are some of just the general thoughts I had:
1. A character is not defined by a class, but is instead defined by a set of attributes. These attributes being:
Bulk, Nerve, Coordination, Reflex, and Memory
2. Characters are also defined by a number of perks, these are either acquired via trainers or via usage of related tools. Using a long rifle will eventually unlock marksman. Being the nozzle holder of a chemical lance eventually unlocks steely nerves.
3. All of a character's actual abilities come from equipment, if you have a sword equipped it has a number of abilities that are part of that sword. You are expected to have equipment that supply abilities in almost every slot.
4. Equipment has attribute requirements, and some have perk requirements in addition (higher end and specialized equipment)

The above is all pretty basic, the ideas I have to try an separate things are:
5. Linked equipment, meaning a single piece of equipment used by two individuals. Examples being a Rotary Gun, A Hog's Head Chemical Lance, etc.
6. Multiple individual units equip the pieces, then stand together and form a single 'Linked Unit' (the guy holding the barrel of the chemical lance and the guy holding the sprayer). Once linked they move as a single larger unit taking up multiple hexes.
7. Different pieces of a linked equipment can have different requirements. Hog's Head chemical lance needs a high Bulk character to carry the barrel and a high Coordination and Nerve character to operate the sprayer.

(1/2)

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1262948
8. Some linked equipment is too large to be carried in pieces, these are Deployable Equipment. An example being Heivel's Breath Cannon, a Rotary Gun, or a Ovic Blemish Sow. These are deployed in a location and units must go to it and then link together.
9. Because of how important larger Deployable Equipment and Linked Units are, encounters can be made harder/easier by limiting deploy locations and spacing out your own unit's deployment zones.
10. The game assumes you unequip/equip items depending on the situation and do so regularly in combat (inventory space per character is important)
11. The exception to this is grafted equipment, which can only be equipped/unequipped by a surgeon literally grafting/removing things from you. This are more powerful at the cost of being stuck in the slot.
12. It isn't only your weapon that will have abilities. A Herbalist's pouch will have abilities when equipped, same for a firearm, and etc. Some items have limited activations (a potion box has limited potions) and have refill actions. A Firearm is fairly simple to refill where as a potion box requires an action that can't be preformed in combat to refill. This makes someone carrying multiple potion boxes a viable option.

These are my thoughts on a tactical grid based RPG. Linked Equipment is meant to encourage multiple characters via allowing them to operate larger things despite being individually weaker. Singular characters are encouraged by high end equipment only being able to be used at high stats. Both playstyles are viable.

On a meta level, the distance scaling factor in the profit calculation makes sense as the default mode because it encourages the player to build a map-spanning network, to spread out as much as possible.
This "no dist pay" mod is really good for multiplayer though, because players will develop their own little corners of the map and leave plenty of room for others. There's no need to compete for space like there is in vanilla MP.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
In A-Train, the longer the distance, the higher the price of the product, but there is a basic economic simulation that will determine the prices of each product in each city, so if you spend too much on transportation, you will make less profit or even a loss.
I think the problem with OpenTTD is that there is no supply and demand simulation to generate prices for commodities or products. There are probably mods solving this problem, though.

>>1249231
I like Railway Empire but I've got a few issues with it:
-UI is trash. Eventually you will have more than 100 locomotives and managing them through that horrible mobile-tier arrow bar is horrible. Keeping track of stuff if you didn't label every single train coherently is a game-ender.
-Laying down double tracks is buggy and sometimes you'll have to wrestle with the system for 5-10 minutes to get them the way you want.
-Mission objectives aren't fully displayed at the start of campaigns so planning ahead is impossible unless you look up a guide. If you're playing to get max score / President this is a big issue.
-Random breakdowns are retarded. They already ask you to build supply stations between every two major settlements, why is this even a thing?
-Towns look like shit.

What I like about it:
+Unlockable talents/upgrades through research.
+Can specialize wagons for extra income.
+Selectable characters with perks to better fit your playstyle.
+Employee system to buff your trains is cool.
+Coherent artstyle and decent voice acting.
+Randomized objectives in free play offers replayability.
+Charts and graphs are easy to understand.
+Can buy resource/production facilities for extra income.

Get 4 frontliners, 2 healers, one wizard or archer, and Canopus with a 2-handed crossbow. Have everyone hang back in the starting area as much as possible (Vyce will rush in, ignore him he's immortal in this part of the game anyway). Meanwhile, you have Canopus spend the first few turns picking up blue physical cards and crit cards, then send him to the corner of the map to pew pew at the necro guy from a safe distance while everyone else tangoes with the undead and hopefully keeps the necro distracted. You'll do like 60 damage per shot (and more on a crit) and the necro will rarely target Canopus unless he's the only available target, so everyone else just plays defense until the necro is worn down by the pew pew. If you're doing well you can send one of the frontliners to beat on the necro to speed things up.

Or just backtrack, do some main story missions, and come back when you're level 7 or 8.

>>1262153
you can also layout your base so that it's easier to get around
a good starrting point is to have 3 columns of 8x4 or even 16x4 rooms seperated by 3 tiles wide columns with doors on each side and ladders/poles inbetween
you want to grow vertically and horizontally as this reduces overall travel time compared to just growing in one direction
it also helps to think about where you place things to reduce travel time for commonly used areas, the kitchen should be relatively close to the storage area/farms for food and also close to the dining area, the toilets and bedrooms should be close together etc
lesser used parts of the facility like medical office or power generation can go at the top/bottom

another useful thing is to assign priorities for tidying, supplying, building, digging etc so you have your dupes picking up tasks they're good at

>>1259338
Use EU4 as a base, but focus more on gameplay and cut the mana system when and where possible. No magic-dev OPM nonsense, and implement a "proposal" system so you can explain the idea to another tag before you go in. Rebels are stronger, states don't automatically centralize, and money is king. Trade is no longer zero-sum, and is tied quite closely to inflation mechanics. More unit composition micro and a wider variety of ship types. Regional wars should be the norm, and there'll be levels of warfare to determine whether or not allies are called in.

This explanation is nonsensical. The warrior aristocrats didn't have to tend to their lands like as if the peasants were some kind of crop, they had stewards for that. Feudal troops stopped because they were duty-bound to only a few tens of days, and Kings rarely had the resources to pay or supply troops for longer than a few months, which also applies to post-feudal troops.

Winter was a bad time to go to war because the harvest was already taken and safely behind walls. Not only was there no forage, but anywhere you attacked was at their strongest because their stores were full.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>1246505
The biggest thing that you're probably not doing if the AI can beat you is magic. Magic is a huge deal in this game. You should be using all the gold that you don't need immediately for winning wars to get more mages – whichever ones give you the most research points per gold. Note that sacred mages have reduced upkeep compared to non-sacreds. You can see upkeep by clicking one of the stats on the unit thing – morale iirc, but I haven't played in a while so hat might have been one of the things they changed going to 5.

Anyway, you also need to evaluate spells. Look at what paths you have (elements) and see what's good. Spells are relatively easy to evaluate, since mostly you just need some badass effects and then counters for whatever your enemy is fielding – but most spells are situational and chances are AI won't field anything that means you need those spells. You can ask here or on /domg/ what your bread and butter spells for a given nation are likely to be.

Mind you, you also ought to be good at building a pretender but that's a lot more in-depth and you kind of have to know what the nation is like. You can ask for specifics about that too.

last_replies.com:
>>1259005
>>1259009
https://eu3.paradoxwikis.com/Domestic_policy_sliders#Centralization_vs._Decentralization

Theres no benefit from not going as much centralized as your form of government allows, maybe even on step beyond that.
The only other related mechanic to keep track of is the overextension triggered modifier, which only ever matters if you have less than 50% (or something similar of your total provinces as core provinces. That means once you conquer enough land and hold it for 50 years, you wont have to bother with overextension any longer.

Additionally, once tech allows for it, you can spam cathedrals, giving you enormous free stability investment that like universities and manufacturies is added as bonus for each manual investment that you make, which gives you insane returns on your stability investments, even allowing for rapid government changes and truce breaking due to the ability to cheaply buy back you stability.

One slider that depends on circumstance is innovative vs narrowminded. If you're catholic, go narrowminded, as large catholic empires will have much greater chances to get new cardinals and take control of the holy see. For anyone else and catholics who stand as the only catholic nation left, lower tech cost afforded by innovative might be the better option.
